content: How can I help you today?

Honestly, I'm not sure if I even want to be here. My wife pushed me to come, and I don’t know if talking about everything is going to make a difference. Things at home just feel like such a mess right now.

Thank you for sharing that. It sounds like you're feeling unsure about being here and whether this will be useful, especially with everything going on at home. It's okay to feel that way. What do you think you're hoping for, if anything, by having this conversation?

I don’t even know what I’m hoping for. I just feel stuck. My son’s behavior has thrown everything out of balance, my marriage feels like it’s falling apart, and I’m failing at being there for my family. I guess I want things to feel normal again, but I don’t even know how to get there.

It sounds like you're carrying a lot right now—trying to handle your son's behavior, your marriage, and feelings of not being there the way you'd like for your family. That feeling of being stuck can be really overwhelming. Wanting things to feel normal again shows how much you care. What does "normal" look like for you?

"Normal" would be coming home to some peace, not walking on eggshells around my wife or dealing with constant chaos from my son. It’d mean feeling like we’re working together as a family, not just arguing or shutting down. I miss spending time with my daughter too—she should have her dad around, but I’ve been so drained. Normal would just be feeling like I have some control over my life again.

It sounds like "normal" for you is having a sense of calm and teamwork in your family, being there for your daughter, and regaining some control in what feels like a chaotic situation. That longing shows how important your family and those connections are to you, even in the midst of everything you're facing. What do you think would need to happen for you to feel even a little closer to that sense of normalcy?

I’m not really sure where to even start. Maybe if my wife and I could be on the same page about how to help our son, that might ease some of the tension. But honestly, everything feels so tangled—I wouldn’t even know how to untangle it all.

It’s understandable that it feels overwhelming when so much is happening at once. Starting somewhere small, like finding common ground with your wife, could feel more manageable. The fact that you're considering ways to address it shows your commitment to change, even if it feels tangled right now. What do you think could help you and your wife begin to work together on this?

It’s hard to say. We’re both so stressed, and whenever we try to talk about our son, it just ends in more arguing. Maybe if we had some kind of outside help—someone who could guide us and help us see things clearly—it’d make a difference. But I don’t know if that’s even realistic.

It sounds like the tension makes it tough to have constructive conversations, but you're open to the idea of someone neutral helping you both navigate this. That shows a lot of insight and willingness to find solutions, even with how overwhelming things feel. What do you think would make it realistic to explore that kind of support?

Maybe if my wife and I could find someone we both trust, like a family counselor, it could be a good first step. I’m not sure how I feel about the whole counseling process, though—it’s new for me, and I’m skeptical about whether it would actually help. But at this point, I guess I don’t see many other options.

It sounds like you're approaching this thoughtfully, even with some uncertainty about counseling. Wanting to find someone you both trust shows how important this is to you and your willingness to try something different for the sake of your family. What about counseling feels like it might be helpful, and what makes you feel skeptical?

It’s just hard to imagine that sitting and talking with someone could actually fix all the things that feel broken right now. But at the same time, I guess having someone guide us might help us figure out how to communicate and deal with things better. I’m just not sure how long it would take or if it’s really worth it.

It's understandable to feel unsure when you're facing so much and not knowing if something new will make a difference. On one hand, the idea of improving communication and finding guidance feels like it could help, but on the other, the uncertainty of time and effort involved makes it challenging to fully commit. It sounds like part of you is willing to consider giving it a chance, even amidst your doubts. What would make you feel more confident that it might be worth trying?

I think if I could see small, real changes—like fewer arguments with my wife or a little progress with my son—it would help me believe it’s worth the effort. I just don’t want to feel like I’m putting in time and energy and still ending up stuck in the same place.

That makes a lot of sense—seeing small, tangible changes could help reassure you that the effort is paying off and that things really can get better. It's clear that you want to invest in this if it leads to progress for your family. What’s one small step, if any, you feel ready to explore that might bring you closer to that kind of change?

Maybe starting with looking into a family counselor that my wife and I could both agree on would be a step. It feels overwhelming, but if it helps us find a way to work together for our son and family, it might be worth trying. I’m nervous about it, but I guess I’m willing to take that first step.

That’s a big step and a meaningful one—to focus on finding someone you and your wife can agree on to help guide you through this together. Being willing to try even when you're feeling nervous shows just how much you care about creating change for your family. Is there anything else you'd like to talk about before moving forward with this idea?
I think I’m okay to end the conversation. Thank you for speaking about this with me.
